section.name: Jelly Integration
section.p: blissed easiest to use by way of the jelly tag library.
The tag library provides a set of tags for defining processes, and a small handful of tags for controlilng processes. Of course, being jelly-based, you can use any other jelly tag library you wish.

section.name: General
section.p: blissed tags can only be used somewhere inside of a <blissed> container element. The container element handles initialization of the system, and acts as a way to group a collection processes together.
section.source:
<!-- || Open a block so that we can use blissed -->
<blissed xmlns="jelly:com.werken.blissed.jelly.BlissedTagLibrary"> ... </blissed>

section.name: Process Definition
section.p: A new process is defined using the <process> tag which requires a unique name attribute. Additional, it must specify the initial start state.
section.source:
<blissed xmlns="jelly:com.werken.blissed.jelly.BlissedTagLibrary">
<!-- || Define a new process named 'process.application' --> <process name="process.application" start="application.complete.check"> ... </process>
</blissed>
section.p: A <process> contains <state> definitions followed by <transition> definitions. Both <state> and <transition> require a name attribute that is unique to the states or transitions for the current <process>. Both may contain a <description> element for providing documentation.
A <state> tag may also contain either a <do-activity> block or <do-process> tag.
section.source:
<process name="process.application" start="application.complete.check">
<!-- || Define a state to check the application for completeness --> <state name="application.complete.check">
<description> Determine if the application contains all required information. </description>
<!-- || Perform this activity block. --> <do-activity> <check-field name="name.first" .../> <check-field name="name.last" .../> <check-field name="address.street" .../> </do-activity>
</state>
<!-- || Define a state to reject an applicant. --> <state name="reject" terminal="true">
<description> Notify applicant of rejection, and give an explanation. </description>
<do-activity> <smtp:send to="${applicant.email}">
Dear ${applicant.name.first},
... ...
</smtp:send> </do-activity>
</state>
<!-- || Define a state start the underwriting process. --> <state name="underwrite">
<description> Send the application through the underwriting process. </description>
<do-process name="process.underwrite"/>
</state>
</process>

section.name: Process Runtime
section.p: Process run-time involves either spawning new processes, or simply using one process as the activity of another. We've already seen how <do-process> can be used for organizational purposes, where when flattened, there is still a single large process.
The <spawn-process> tag can be used to either spawn a new top-level process or to create a nested, child processes from an already existing process.

Like <do-process>, the <spawn-process> takes a single name attribute specifying the process name. It will always create a new Thread for the execution of the process. If the <spawn-process> occurs outside of an <do-activity> tag, then a top-level process is created, otherwise, a child of the current process is created.
section.source:
<!-- || Open a block so that we can use blissed -->
<blissed xmlns="jelly:com.werken.blissed.jelly.BlissedTagLibrary"> ... <process name="process.application"> <state name="notify.others"> <do-activity> <!-- || Spawn two concurrent process to perform || notifications. This process continues || even before these terminate. --> <spawn process="notify.internal-orgs"/> <spawn process="notify.external-orgs"/> </do-activity> </state>
</process>
<process.. /> <process.. />
<!-- || Spawn the top-level process for an application. --> <spawn-process name="process.application"/>
</blissed>
